important_phrase: Most District farms benefited from precipitation that improved soil moisture conditions
Commercial real estate activity softened further as vacancy rates rose, rents declined, and more projects were delayed
Construction and manufacturing firms reported that raw material prices had generally moderated by mid-August after having increased in late spring
Banking contacts continued to remark that credit availability remained tight
Most manufacturers indicated that their outlook for future production and sales improved
Both Realtors and homebuilders noted that increases in supply because of foreclosures and short-sales were partially responsible for the price declines even as sales increased
Most industry contacts reported lower revenues, and reduced profit margins
Many business contacts in the First District report recent signs of improvement, although most say activity remains below year-earlier levels
Contacts note that clients are currently hiring to fill vacancies, rather than hiring to expand
New England software and information technology firms report mixed results, with some experiencing continued slowdowns while others have begun to see modest improvement
Home sales increased between 4 percent and 13 percent year-over-year across the region
Contacts note that headcounts are stable
Cool temperatures slowed maturation and both crops continued to trail the pace of normal development
The pace of job loss slowed, and credit conditions improved
In contrast, utility costs softened a bit, and the price of natural gas remained very low
Credit conditions in the District improved from the previous reporting period
The decline in business spending slowed in July and August
Single-family home sales increased and prices stabilized
Overall consumer spending increased in July and August
Coal executives reported a sharp decline in production, which they attributed to very weak demand from electric utilities
The economy in the Fourth District has shown a slight improvement since our last report, though activity remains sluggish
Interest rates and credit spreads are either holding steady or increasing slightly
Several transport executives reported having difficulty renewing or increasing their lines of credit
Reports on nonresidential construction were mixed, with some improvement seen by contractors participating in public works projects
Most dealers are uncertain about future sales due to weak economic conditions and difficulties in obtaining credit
Drilling has slowed sharply in the Gulf of Mexico, including deep water drilling
Despite the slight improvement, several contacts expressed disappointment that conditions had not improved more
Stffing firms noted a slight improvement in demand, and there were reports from high-tech and paper respondents that temporary hiring had edged up
There were scattered reports of improvement in loan demand over the past six weeks, although contacts remain cautious about the future
Respondents in high-tech manufacturing said orders increased moderately since the last report
Commercial leasing activity remains sluggish
Retailers report that consumers remain cautious, keeping overall sales flat at low levels
Wile agricultural growing conditions remained positive, income projections weakened slightly since the last survey period
Wge pressures remained low and few firms planned to hire new workers
Producer prices generally held steady while consumer prices eased, and soft labor markets kept wage pressures low
Deposits rose moderately after showing little change in the previous survey
Durable goods production dropped while non-durable goods production held steady
Wile residential real estate agents noted increased buyer traffic, building suppliers reported slower sales to builders for new home construction
In addition, fewer dealers reported difficulty accessing credit
Activity in the energy and mining sectors increased slightly
Labor markets were mixed, and wage increases were subdued
Wge increases were subdued
Architects reported extremely low activity levels--the same as the last report
Residential real estate showed continued improvement
Tourism was mixed, as visitor numbers were solid, but spending was soft in some areas
Reports on agricultural activity were mixed
Most Districts reported improvements in manufacturing production
Wge pressures remained low across all Districts
Mortgage activity declined modestly according to the Philadelphia, Cleveland, and Kansas City Districts, while Richmond reported increases attributed to improved demand for starter homes
Most Districts reported modest improvements in the manufacturing sector
Construction remained at very low levels, with modest improvements noted in public construction in the Chicago, Cleveland, and Minneapolis Districts
Consumer spending remained soft in most Districts
Consumer confidence improved slightly in August but is still at a low level
For all loan categories, respondents indicate ongoing tightening of credit standards
Firms across most sectors continue to report increases in prices paid but modest declines in prices received
Industrial markets have been mixed but mostly steady
Contacts report modest improvement in credit conditions for consumers
Service sector firms reported mainly steady activity at a slow pace
Some home builders reported rising construction costs due to increased local government permit fees
One banker noted that "we are being more selective" in lending, and posting slower loan growth as a result
Although the number of firms expecting improvement has increased, most expect gains to be slight
Rents have declined
The sales spurt reduced dealers' inventories significantly
In other areas however, widespread rainfall significantly improved field crops and hayfields
Wile economic reports from Fifth District business contacts continued to indicate a relatively weak economy, continuing signs of improvement were apparent in many sectors
Several contacts, however, noted some improvement and were optimistic about demand over the next few weeks due to the improving economy and an increase in manufacturing orders
Residential mortgage lenders reported slow but steady activity in recent weeks
" Wges at services businesses continued to decline while prices edged down slightly
Residential real estate agents reported generally improved housing market conditions in recent weeks
Contacts at home and garden businesses, department stores, and retail establishments said sales declined in recent weeks
Demand for agricultural products stayed solid, while demand remained somewhat weak for extractors of natural resources used for energy production
District manufacturing activity remained stuck at very low levels, although conditions improved further for manufacturers of information technology products

Contacts noted that, despite an anticipated improvement in economic conditions, they expect hiring to remain subdued for a prolonged period as companies focus on maintaining recent productivity improvements rather than expanding employment; accordingly, they expect upward wage pressures to remain muted for some time
District banking contacts reported that loan demand softened further during the reporting period
Makers of commercial aircraft and parts saw further significant declines in new and existing orders, and they reduced production activity accordingly
Moreover, new home construction remained at very low levels throughout the District
Contacts in the restaurant and food services industry noted weak demand and further declines in revenues
The overall condition of the corn, soybeans, rice, cotton, and sorghum crops in the District has improved slightly: No more than 10 percent of each crop obtained a rating of poor
Both manufacturing and services activity contracted at a slower pace
Meanwhile, credit standards for consumer loans were basically unchanged, while demand for these loans was mixed, ranging from moderately weaker to moderately stronger
Manufacturing activity continued to decline since our previous survey, but at a slower pace
Downtown office vacancy rates remained fairly constant in St Louis, increased in Louisville and Memphis, and decreased in Little Rock
Lawn and garden products and less-expensive items were strong sellers, while apparel and big-ticket items moved more slowly
